Generally, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is used as feedstock to produce 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA). Whereas, its poor stability in alkaline environment results in low yield of FDCA. By contrast, 5-[(formyloxy)methyl]furfural (FMF), a novel platform compound derived from HMF, with higher thermal and alkaline stability than HMF, is more promising to replace HMF as substrate for the production of FDCA. In this study, FMF was successfully converted into FDCA over MoCuOx by using NaClO as oxidant, undergoing 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) and 5-hydroxymethylfuran-2-carboxylic acid (HMFCA) as intermediates. Under optimization condition (30 min, 40 °C), 100% yield of FDCA was obtained. Furthermore, it was also demonstrated that the yield of FDCA up to 90% was gained in 5 wt % FMF concentration. Higher oxygen species mobility and lattice oxygen ratio endowed MoCuOx excellent catalytic activity. The synergy of Mo and Cu species in MoCuOx ensured an efficient conversion of HMF to FDCA through synergistic redox couple of Mo6+/Mo5+ and Cu2+/Cu+. Graphical abstract A novel protocol for the transformation of FMF into FDCA with NaClO as oxidant over the bimetal MoCuOx catalyst. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxidation 5-[(formyloxy)methyl]furfural 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid MoCuOx NaClO 1 Introduction In the context of green sustainable development, biorefinery has attracted tremendous inquisitiveness for the green production of renewable chemicals and biofuels to alleviate excessive reliance on fossil energy [1–3]. Especially, one of the promising applications of cellulosic platform compound (5-hydroxymethylfurfural: HMF) is the production of 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) by oxidation [4,5]. FDCA is regarded as a renewable alternative to replace terephthalic acid (PTA) for the preparation of polyester such as polyethylene furoate (PEF) [6–8]. However, industrial production of PEF still faces challenge under the conditions of FDCA production cost. The oxidation of HMF to prepare FDCA over homogeneous and heterogeneous catalyst has been extensively investigated [9,10]. For homogeneous catalysts, the Co(OAc)2-Mn(OAc)2-HBr or Co(OAc)2-Zn(OAc)2-NaBr catalytic system has been studied for the preparation of FDCA from HMF using the O2 as oxidant in acetic acid [11]. However, the yield of FDCA remains to be improved in this case because of the serious side reactions of HMF in the acidic environment. In addition, Hansen et al. used t-BuOOH as the oxidant instead of O2 for the conversion of HMF to FDCA over CuCl2 or CuCl-LiBr, and finally offered a low FDCA yield (< 50%) [12]. The heterogeneous catalysts have been widely investigated for the production of FDCA from HMF due to low catalytic performance and recyclability of homogeneous catalysts [13]. Noble metal-based catalysts, such as supported Pt, Pd, Au, and Ru catalysts, were demonstrated excellent performance for the for the oxidation of HMF into FDCA [6,14]. However, the high cost of noble metals limited their large-scale application in industry and promoted the development of inexpensive transition-metal catalysts. Recently, satisfactory yields of FDCA (99% < yield) were obtained over Fe-, Mn-, Co-, and Cu-based catalyst under harsh condition (100–160 °C, 1–5.5 MPa O2 or air, 10–48 h) [3]. Nevertheless, the harsh reaction conditions as well as low catalytic efficiency led to poor economic effect of FDCA production. Generally, the production of FDCA requires to add alkaline to the reaction owing to its low solubility in most solvents. most previous works on the conversion of HMF to FMF have focused only on low substrate concentrations around 0.5–2.1 wt%, owing to the poor stability of concentrated HMF in alkaline environment [4,11,15,16]. Compared with HMF, FMF is regarded as a novel biomass-derived chemical due to its high stability and hydrophobicity. In our lab, one-pot and two-step preparation of FMF from biomass-derived carbohydrates using formic acid with purity of more than 98.8% have been developed [17–19]. FMF can be separated from the reaction mixture by extraction and distillation, and because the formyloxymethyl group is less hydrophilic than the hydroxyl group it is easier to separate and purify than HMF. However, few works focused on developing effective approach for the production of FDCA form more accessible FMF. Especially, the production of FMF from cellulose in one-pot had been developed by our group. To bridge cellulose and FDCA, herein, the synthesis of FDCA by the oxidation of 5-[(formyloxy)methyl]furfural (FMF) was investigated over the MoCuOx catalyst with NaClO as oxidant. In an initial study, a complete conversion of FMF and FDCA yield of more than 99% were obtained under a mild reaction condition. Inspired by this result, the effects of MoCuOx on the oxidation of FMF to FDCA and the underlying catalytic mechanism were studied in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials FMF (C7H6O4, 98%) was prepared and purified in our laboratory. Jiang et al. designed a one-pot approach to prepare FMF from cellulose in formic acid reaction system with a yield of 33.4 mol% at 150 °C for 2 h and later Xiong et al. established a two-step approach to prepare FMF via HMF in choline chloride (ChCl)/fructose deep eutectic solvents (DES) system. The FMF with a purity of 98.8% was obtained finally [17,18]. FDCA (98%), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA) (98%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. HMF (98%), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (99%), NaMoO4 ·2H2O (99%), and MoO3 (99%) were bought from Aladdin Reagent Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). 7.5 wt% NaClO aqueous solution, CuO (99%), Na2CO3 (99%) were acquired from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company Co. Ltd (Shanghai, China). 2.2 Catalyst preparation The MoCuOx samples were synthesized according to the deposition precipitation method. Briefly, 2.4 g of NaMoO4·2H2O was dissolved in 50 mL of water, and then 2.4 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was added into the mixture, wherein the Mo/Cu molar ratio was 1.0. The mixture was stirred for 24 h at 80 °C, then the solvent of turbid liquid was evaporated to dryness overnight at 70 °C. The recovered solid calcined under air atmosphere at 500 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace and washed with distilled water, dried overnight at 100 °C, denoted as MoCuOx. The catalyst characterizations are presented in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Production of FDCA from FMF General procedure for the aerobic oxidation of 5-[(formyloxy)methyl]furfural (FMF): 0.1 g of FMF, 0.04 g of MoCuOx (40 wt% relative to the FMF) were added to 5.0 g of 7.5 wt% NaClO aqueous solution into a boiling flask (50 mL). The reactor was sealed under air at atmospheric pressure, and the mixture was conducted at the required reaction temperature for a specific reaction time with magnetic stirring. After the reaction, the boiling flask was cooled down to room temperature with an ice bath. Then, the reaction product was centrifuged and the solid MoCuOx was collected by filtration. Finally, 100 g of deionized water was diluted and 0.005 M H2SO4 aqueous solution were used as the mobile phase for HPLC analysis. The extraction was performed with ethyl acetate for several times. Then, the resulting extract solution was collected and dehydrated by anhydrous magnesium sulfate for further analysis. The analyses of samples are presented in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst selection and reaction condition optimization Based on the higher stability of FMF than HMF, we attempted to establish a mild catalytic reaction system to efficiently prepare FDCA from FMF. In many previous studies, both CuO and MoO3 were usually employed in various oxidation processes owing to their high activity and selectivity [20–22]. CuO was also reported served as the efficient catalyst for the conversion of pure HMF into FDCA by using NaClO as oxidant at 40 °C for 2 h [20]. The synergy of MoO3/Cu(NO3)2 was also verified in the conversion of HMF to phthalic anhydride in our previous study [19]. Cu2+ efficiently strengthened the redox of Mo6+/Mo4+in the oxidation HMF to furan radical. Initially, the oxidation FMF to FDCA was carried out over the synthetic Cu/Mo-based oxides. As depicted in Table 1 , entries 1,2, a poor FDCA yield was obtained with 100% conversion of FMF, which is because that low catalytic activity of separate CuO or MoO3 leads the non-selective oxidation of FMF. Whereupon the idea of adding CuO by physical mixing to promote the activity of MoO3 was examined, however, no visible change was observed in the yield of FDCA (Table 1, entry 3). Generally, bimetallic oxide catalyst is functioned well than physical mixed oxide catalysts. Hence, the bimetallic oxides, MoCuOx, were synthesized by co-precipitation method for the oxidation of FMF. As expected, a 100% yield of FDCA was obtained under the investigated condition (Table 1, entry 4). Moreover, the recovered catalyst remained a high activity for the next run (Table 1, entries 6,7). To achieve high conversion efficiency, optimizing reaction parameters, such as reaction time and temperature, were conducted. The results clearly showed that both increasing temperature and prolonging time would lead to the decrease in the FDCA yield (Fig. S1a and b). Actually, 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA) and HMF were detected in the oxidation of FMF to FDCA over MoCuOx, moreover, they gradually disappeared with the prolongation of the reaction time from 1 to 40 min (Fig. S1b). This finding indicates that HMFCA and HMF probably is the main intermediate for the oxidation of FMF in this reaction. In addition, 2, 5-diformylfuran (DFF) was detected by GC–MS during the oxidation of FMF to FDCA under an ice bath (Fig. S2). These results demonstrate the conversion of FMF to FDCA may undergo two reaction paths via multiple reaction intermediates. Generally, in the oxidation of HMF to FDCA, the higher the concentration of HMF, the lower the yield of FDCA. The comparative studies for FMF and HMF as feedstock showed that an analogous yield of FDCA was obtained when in 2 wt% concentration, whereas a relatively lower yield of FDCA for HMF in 5 wt% concentration (Fig. S3). More than 90% yield of FDCA was achieved when FMF in 5 wt%, which indicated that MoCuOx performed well in the oxidation of FMF to FDCA, even in a high FMF concentration. Intriguingly, the hydrolysis of FMF in basic-solution was only around 15% (Table S1), demonstrating the hydrolysis equilibrium of FMF to HMF in the reaction. The hydrolysis equilibrium ensured the low concentration of HMF, facilitating the conversion of HMF to FDCA. Collectively, it is concluded that the hydrolysis equilibrium of FMF with HMF is formed initially, then FMF or HMF is oxidized to DFF and HMFCA as intermediates by hydration and dehydrogenation, respectively, eventually to FDCA via the intermediate FFCA (Fig. S1c). 3.2 Characterization of catalyst The excellent performance of MoCuOx suggests a synergy of Mo and Cu species enable the facile oxidation of FMF to FDCA. To bridge the catalytic activity and structure of MoCuOx, MoCuOx was determined by X-ray diffraction pattern (XRD) measurement (Fig. 1 ). The diffraction peaks of the synthetic MoCuOx composite exhibited two different phase structures coexisting [23] such as orthorhombic crystal system (α-MoO3) with 2θ values of 12.76, 23.33, 25.70, 27.34 and 38.98°, corresponding to the crystal planes of (020), (110), (040), (021), (060), and CuO exhibits monoclinic system with 2θ values of 35.49, 38.96°, corresponding to the crystal planes of (002), (200) [24–26]. The characteristic diffraction peaks of MoO3 (JCPDS card No. 05-0508) and CuO (JCPDS card No. 45-0937) were included into the characteristic XRD patterns of the synthetic MoCuOx, indicating the coexistence of MoO3 and CuO. Furthermore, several weak characteristic peaks that were assigned neither MoO3 nor CuO especially in the 2θ region (20−30°) were observed, probably contributing to the formation of Mo/Cu bimetallic oxide due to the incorporation of Cu species in the structure of MoO3 by the coprecipitation method. Contrasted the catalytic activity of MoCuOx with the physically mixed MoO3/CuO, it is indicated that the interaction of Mo and Cu species plays a crucial role in the oxidation of FMF to FDCA. Whereupon, the structural characteristics was analyzed. The morphologies of CuO, MoO3, and the MoCuOx composite were observed by SEM and TEM (Figs. S4 and 2 ). Pure CuO presented a round rod -like morphology (Fig. S4a), while MoO3 showed obvious edges and grain-like morphology (Fig. S4b) [23,26,27]. As for the MoCuOx composite, the regular hexagonal sheet structure was observed with the nanoparticle of CuO adhered on its smooth surface (Fig. 2a). This structure ensured the large contact surface between CuO and MoO3, which is beneficial to the transfer of electron from Cu 2p to Mo 3d The EDX elemental maps analysis demonstrated that Mo, Cu and O elements were uniform dispersed in MoCuOx (Fig. 2b). The synthetic MoCuOx characterized the inferior BET surface area, however it performed excellent in the oxidation of FMF to FDCA, which indicated that this oxidation was controlled by the electron transfer velocity between the catalyst with the substrates, instead of the absorption of the substrate on the surface of the catalyst (Table S2). In the TEM image of MoCuOx (Fig. 2c), the grain-like profile of MoO3 was observed with adhered nanoparticle CuO (Fig. S4 c,d). MoCuOx was further investigated by the high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) to figure out its morphology and crystal size/shape. As shown in Fig. 2 d,e, the lattice fringe spaces of 0.2164, 0.3068 and 0.33466 nm assigning to the (060), (042) and (062) crystal planes of MoO3 were observed. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig. 2f) exhibited the separate points, corresponding to the (040), (111) and (020) planes of MoO3, illustrating a good orthorhombic crystal structure. In order to identify the surface species of Mo, Cu and O, MoCuOx, MoO3 and CuO were examined by XPS measurement (Fig. 3 ). As shown in Fig. 3a, the strong peaks of Mo 3d were located around 232.9 eV and 236.0 eV, respectively, implying the main species of Mo6+ in MoCuOx [28]. Two peaks located around 954.2 and 934.0 eV were assigned to the Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 peaks of Cu2+ (Fig. 3b) [29]. Compared with MoO3 and CuO, the binding energy of the Mo 3d of MoCuOx had been shifted down by 0.2 eV, whereas 0.3–0.4 eV up-shift for Cu 2p. These results clearly demonstrate actual existence of electron transfer tendency from Cu 2p to Mo 3d, further testifying the strong interaction between Mo and Cu species. The O 1s XPS spectrum of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 3c. The O 1s spectra of catalysts are fitted with two peak contributions [30]. The peak between 529.8 and 530.8 eV was corresponded to lattice oxygen (labeled as Olat) and the peak between 532.0 and 531.5 eV was assigned to the surface non-lattice oxygen species (labeled as Onon-lat) resulting from the hydroxyl species (OH) [30–35]. As for CuO, the BE of O1 s core level for Cu(II) was lower than that of MoO3, being due to the presence of d-electrons in the Cu(II) cation, while no outermost d-electrons for Mo (VI). The BE of O1s core level in MoCuOx was located at somewhere in between. Apparently, the Olat/ (Olat +Onon-lat) ratio of MoCuOx (88.2%) was higher than that of MoO3 (60.6%) and CuO (57.6%), which is in good accordance with the order of the catalytic activity for the conversion of FMF to FDCA. The poor selectivity to FDCA from FMF for CuO or MoO3 probably contributed to its more hydroxylated surface, which characterized by the poor oxidation selectivity for the oxidation of FMF. In addition, Mo5+ were detected in the used MoCuOx (Fig. S5a). Further, Auger Cu LMM spectra identified Cu+ species located at BE 574 eV (Fig. S5b) [36–38]. These results suggested that Mo6+ & Cu2+ were reduced during the catalytic reaction. The O 1s XPS spectra of the recovered MoCuOx is shown in Fig. S5c. Lattice oxygen (denoted as Olat) and surface non-lattice oxygen species (denoted as Onon-lat) was located at 530.2 eV and 532.0 eV, respectively [31,32,39]. The ratio of Olat/(Olat+Onon-lat) decreased from 88.2 to 19.6%, indicating the lattice oxygen of the catalyst involves in the oxidation FMF to FDCA. The O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) was further employed to evaluate the mobility of oxygen species on MoO3, CuO and MoCuOx (Fig. 4 a). The O2-TPD profiles were divided into three stages: the desorption peak of oxygen at low temperature (LT, < 300 °C) resulted from surface capping oxygen [40], the peak at medium temperature (MT, 300–580 °C) corresponded to the removal of surface oxygen species [41], and the peaks at high temperature (HT, > 580 °C) was assigned to the release of bulk lattice oxygen [28]. Obviously, MoO3 showed the weak peak at 92 °C, two strong peaks at 373 and 401 °C and inconspicuous broad peak over 580 °C. For CuO, the peak centered at 456 °C and insignificant broad peak over 580 °C were observed. Especially for MoCuOx, the small peak appeared at the range of 400–550 °C and the strong peak occurred at 677 °C. It was worth noting that more adsorption oxygen on MoO3 and CuO than that of MoCuOx in the MT stage [42]. By contrary, the lattice oxygen desorption from the three catalysts followed the order: MoCuOx >> CuO > MoO3. Combined with the catalytic activity of the three catalysts, the lattice oxygen should be the main active oxygen species involved in the oxidation of FMF to FDCA. Generally, beside excellent oxygen mobility, oxidation activity of catalyst also depends on amount of oxygen supplying centers [26,43]. Further, thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) were performed to evaluate the mobility of the lattice oxygen for these three catalysts (Fig. 4b). As shown in the TG curve, the inconspicuous weight loss occurred in the range of 96–300 °C, assigning to the desorption of the physically adsorbed water on the surface of the three catalysts. The significant loss mass occurred over 800 °C for MoO3 and CuO, while more than 25% loss mass was observed below 750 °C. In summary, the thermal stability and relative weight loss of these three catalysts followed the tendency: MoCuOx >> MoO3 > CuO below 800 °C, further verifying the better lattice oxygen mobility of MoCuOx compared to the monometallic oxides. Eventually, MoO3 exhibited more mass loss than MoCuOx and CuO, suggesting its more oxygen supplying centers. Combined these results with Mars-van-Krevelen mechanism deduced that the lattice oxygen with higher mobility is responsible for the oxidation of FMF [44]. H2-TPR analysis was performed to investigate the relative reducibility of these three catalysts, as shown in Fig. 4c. For CuO, strong reduction peak of H2 consumption were observed at 266 °C attributing to the reduction of the crystalline CuO [45]. As for MoO3, the shoulder peak of the H2 consumption was observed at 603 and 645 °C, corresponding to the reduction process of Mo6+ [46]. Whereas for MoCuOx, four peaks of H2 consumption were observed at 154 °C, 194 °C, 508 °C and 517 °C, respectively. The former two reduction peaks may be attributed to the reduction stages of CuO to Cu2O and Cu2O to Cu, respectively. And the latter two stages were assigned to the two-step reduction from Mo6+ to Mo4+ via Mo5+. Obviously, MoCuOx had better reducibility than that of MoO3 and CuO according to the decreased reduction temperature. Furthermore, O2-TPO analysis was employed to investigate the oxidability of the three recovered catalysts after the reaction. As shown in Fig. 4d, for the recovered MoO3, the oxygen consumption peaks between 364 and 519 °C corresponded to the multi-step oxidation of Mo4+ to Mo6+ [47], while the recovered CuO showed only one peak centered at 380 °C. Obviously, the oxygen consumption required for the recovered catalysts followed the rule of MoO3 ≫ CuO > MoCuOx, meaning that MoCuOx had the stronger oxygen coordination capacity under oxygen atmosphere compared to MoO3 and CuO because of its the less oxygen consumption, lower oxidation temperature range and better catalytic performance. 3.3 Catalytic mechanism To elucidate the synergistic catalytic mechanism of Cu and Mo species of MoCuOx in the conversion of FMF to FDCA, furfural and furfuryl alcohol were employed to analyze the interaction of the carbonyl group and hydroxyl group with the surface of the catalysts (Fig. 5 ). When furfural was absorbed on the surface of MoO3 or CuO, the apparent red-shifts of the characteristic absorption peaks, such as C1 O1 in O-terminal adsorption at 1673 cm−1, C1−H1 at 1392 cm−1 were found, moreover, the red-shift for MoO3 was more significant, inferring that Mo species played a main role in the adsorption of the aldehyde group in HMF relative to the Cu species. However, the changes associated with the furan-ring were not observed (Fig. S6a,b) [48–51]. Therefore, it is believed that C1 O1 has been activated with O-terminal adsorption without affecting the furan ring on MoO3 or CuO. Whereupon, it is proposed a tilted or vertical adsorption geometry of furfural on MoO3 and CuO by the O-terminal adsorption of C1 O1 on the surface of MoO3 and CuO with the furan ring away from the catalyst surface. For MoCuOx, the absorption peaks associated with C1 O1 shifted to lower region (Fig. 5a), suggesting that the adsorption configuration of furfural on MoCuOx is similar to that on these two monometallic oxides. When furfuryl alcohol as substrate, the blue-shift for the O1 H1 bond was more significant for MoO3 (3326 to 3362 cm−1) than CuO (Fig. S6c,d), meaning that hydroxyl group was preferentially adsorbed on Mo species [49]. By contrast, no adsorption behavior was observed for the furan-ring of furfuryl alcohol. In the case of MoCuOx, only the absorption peaks associated with O1 H1 bond shifted to higher region relative to MoO3 or CuO (Fig. 5b), showing that the adsorption configuration of furfural alcohol on MoCuOx was similar to that on MoO3. Taken together, it is inferred that the adsorption of furfuryl alcohol was adsorbed on the surface of MoO3, CuO or MoCuOx by the C1 O1 bond in a tilted or vertical configuration with the furan ring away the surface of the catalysts [20]. In the oxidation of HMF, the separate MoO3 or CuO showed the similar yield of FDCA, however higher catalytic efficiency for MoO3 than CuO (Tables S3,4). To validate the oxidizing power of NaClO to aldehyde and hydroxyl groups, the oxidation of DFF and HMFCA by NaClO were conducted without catalyst. The FDCA yields of 59 and 22% were achieved (Table S5, entry 1,2), suggesting that NaClO functioned well in the oxidation of aldehyde group, however, only poor efficiency for the oxidation of hydroxyl group to aldehyde group. In addition, the relation between the catalysts and NaClO was also investigated (Fig. S7). A lot of bubbles were formed when MoCuOx or MoO3 was added in the NaClO solution, accompanying with the gradually increasing temperature of the reaction solution, which indicated that MoO3 and MoCuOx accelerated the reduction of NaClO. It also meant that invalid oxygen was released during the oxidation of FMF. However, the relatively gentle bubble was released when CuO was added into the NaClO solution, the mild reduction of NaClO to active oxygen meant more invalid active oxygen, promoting the oxygen efficiency of HMF to FDCA by NaClO. Combined the adsorption characteristic of the aldehyde and hydroxyl groups on MoO3 and CuO with their oxidation activity for HMF, it was further confirmed that the activation of hydroxyl group on MoO3 played a major role in the oxidation of hydroxyl group to aldehyde group, then to carboxyl group. However, CuO only played role in the oxidation of aldehyde group to carboxyl group. In the precious study [19], the combination of MoO3 and Cu(NO3)2 showed excellent catalytic activity for the oxidation of HMF active furan intermediate. It was confirmed that the catalytic activity of MoO3 was promoted by the redox of Cu2+/Cu+. Moreover, Mo5+ and Cu+ were detected in the used MoCuOx (Fig. S5a,b). Based on the excellent catalytic activity of MoCuOx, it is speculated that the synergy of the redox couple of Mo6+/Mo5+ and Cu2+/Cu+ played a vital role in the oxidation of FMF to FDCA. According to the function of Mo and Cu species in the oxidation of HMF to FDCA, it is deduced that the redox couple of Mo6+/Mo5+ mainly functions to oxidize hydroxyl group to aldehyde group and oxidize the hydroxyl group of HMFCA to FFCA. More importantly, the redox couple of Cu2+/Cu+ synergistical improved the catalytic activity of the redox couple of Mo6+/Mo5+ for the oxidation of FMF to FDCA. To sum up, compared with MoO3 and CuO, the synthetic MoCuOx has more lattice oxygen with higher mobility and lattice oxygen ratio, improving the oxidation of FMF to FDCA. The synergy of Cu and Mo species in MoCuOx ensured the highly efficient oxidation of FMF to FDCA by a tilt or vertical adsorption by the hydroxyl group and aldehyde group on the surface of MoCuOx. The redox couple of Mo6+/Mo5+ mainly functioned to oxidize hydroxyl group to aldehyde group, then to carboxyl group, whereas the redox couple of Cu2+/Cu+ main for the oxidation of aldehyde group to aldehyde group. The synergy of the redox couple of Mo6+/Mo5+ between Cu2+/Cu+ further enhanced the oxidation efficiency of FMF or HMF to FDCA Scheme 1. Building upon our previous studies [52,53], a plausible mechanism for the oxidation of FMF to FDCA using NaClO as oxidant over MoCuOx catalyst is proposed. As illustrated in Scheme 2. Initially, the hydrolysis equilibrium of FMF to HMF is formed. Then the hydroxyl group and aldehyde group of HMF as the intermediate are adsorbed onto MoCuOx mainly through the O-terminal adsorption between the O1 H1, C1=O1 with the Mo species in MoCuOx, respectively, followed by the oxidation to DFF and HMFCA mediated by the agem-diol intermediate through hydration reaction over Mo6+-O-Cu2+ sites of MoCuOx. Meanwhile, the partial aldehyde group is also adsorbed onto Cu species on the surface of MoCuOx by the C1=O1, and then oxidized into HMFCA by the agem-diol intermediate [29,54]. Similarly, the dehydrogenation of HMFCA to FFCA, followed by hydration and dehydrogenation to FDCA, occurs over Mo6+-O-Cu2+ sites of MoCuOx by the same reaction mechanism. In the oxidation, Mo6+ species are reduced to Mo5+ species, meanwhile the redox of Cu2+/Cu+ synergistically promoted the regeneration of Mo6+ [54,55]. Afterward, the re-oxidation of Cu+ to Cu2+ was accomplished with an involvement of the active oxygen originated from ClO−, accompanied by the refill of the generated oxygen vacancy. 3.4 Leaching test and catalyst recirculation The stability and reusability performance of the catalyst were evaluated by the leaching and recycling tests. As shown in Fig. 6 a, after leaching the catalyst at 15 min and then the reaction was continued for 15 min, the yield of FDCA nearly remained at an identical level. Furthermore, the recycling tests of MoCuOx for the oxidation of FMF to FDCA were also carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 6b. The catalytic activity of the recovered MoCuOx still retained a high level after the fifth run. For the recovered catalyst, the binging energies corresponding to Mo5+ and Cu+ were observed, however, the used MoCuOx in O2 showed no significant difference from those of the fresh catalyst (Fig. S5). The regenerated MoCuOx also showed catalytic activity similar to that of the fresh one. The excellent reusability performance of MoCuOx confirmed the re-oxidation of the reduced Mo and Cu species to Mo6+ and Cu2+ by the fresh NaClO in the cycle experiment. 4 Conclusion Summarily, this work described a novel protocol for the transformation of FMF into FDCA with NaClO as oxidant over the bimetal MoCuOx catalyst. Under the optimized conditions (30 min, 40 °C), the 100% yield of FDCA was obtained. The reaction was initiated at the hydrolysis equilibrium of FMF to HMF, ensuring a low concentration of HMF for the following oxidation to DFF or HMFCA, then the further oxidation to FFCA, eventually to FDCA. More lattice oxygen ratio and oxygen species mobility made MoCuOx perform excellent in the oxidation of FMF to FDCA. The synergy between Mo and Cu species in MoCuOx played a key role in the simultaneous activation of carbonyl group (C=O) and hydroxyl group (-OH) by the adsorption of aldehyde and hydroxyl groups by a tilted or vertical configuration with the furan ring away the surface of the catalyst. Furthermore, it was also demonstrated that the aerobic oxidation of FMF with the concentration of 5 wt% gave a FDCA yield up to 90% over MoCuOx. coredata.dc:description: Generally, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is used as feedstock to produce 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA). Whereas, its poor stability in alkaline environment results in low yield of FDCA. By contrast, 5-[(formyloxy)methyl]furfural (FMF), a novel platform compound derived from HMF, with higher thermal and alkaline stability than HMF, is more promising to replace HMF as substrate for the production of FDCA. In this study, FMF was successfully converted into FDCA over MoCuOx by using NaClO as oxidant, undergoing 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) and 5-hydroxymethylfuran-2-carboxylic acid (HMFCA) as intermediates. Under optimization condition (30 min, 40 °C), 100% yield of FDCA was obtained. Furthermore, it was also demonstrated that the yield of FDCA up to 90% was gained in 5 wt % FMF concentration. Higher oxygen species mobility and lattice oxygen ratio endowed MoCuOx excellent catalytic activity. The synergy of Mo and Cu species in MoCuOx ensured an efficient conversion of HMF to FDCA through synergistic redox couple of Mo6+/Mo5+ and Cu2+/Cu+.
coredata.dc:title: Aerobic oxidation of 5-[(formyloxy)methyl]furfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid over MoCuOx catalyst
